title: Sophos shares soar 37% after $3.8 billion offer from US buyout group
text:
Another UK company fell into foreign hands on Monday after US private equity group Thoma Bravo agreed to buy Sophos SOPH, +35.84% in an all-cash deal which values the British cyber security group at $3.8 billion (£3.1 billion) including debt.

The deal is the first acquisition outside the US for San Francisco-based Thoma Bravo, which is one of the most active investors in technology businesses. It has struck more than 200 deals worth a total $50 billion since 2003, including a stake in the cybersecurity-software company McAfee last year and the $3.7 billion buyout of mortgage software company Ellie Mae in February.

Sophos shareholders will receive $7.40 in cash (583 pence) per share, a 37.1% premium to the company’s closing share price of 425.5 pence on Friday. However, the exact amount received by investors will vary depending on the exchange rate at the time of completion, subject to regulatory clearance.

Shares in Sophos Group PLC soared 37% on news of the deal and were trading at 578 pence in London.

“One thing worth bearing in mind is that the offer is denominated in dollars, and given the volatility we’ve seen in sterling recently that means the final pounds and pence value of the deal could end up being significantly different to that reported today,” warned Nicholas Hyett, Equity Analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2020.

Hyett added: “If sterling weakens then that’s good news for UK investors, but should a Brexit deal be agreed, a rally in sterling could leave investors out of pocket. For those unwilling to stomach the volatility and who want to lock in the current price, it might make sense to sell the shares now rather than hold on until the deal completes – even if that does rule out the possibility of a bump in price from any rival bid.”

Sophos, which is based in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, was floated in 2015 by private equity firm by Apax Partners for £1bn, at a time when cyber security products were in demand in the wake of several high-profile ransomware attacks. Its customers include Under Armour UAA, +1.78%, Ford Motor F, +1.86%, and Xerox XRX, +2.05%

However, in January, the FTSE-250 company saw its shares fall by 25% after suffering a decline in lower annual billings as hardware and sales to new customers fell.

Seth Boro, managing partner at Thoma Bravo said: “Sophos has a market-leading product portfolio and we believe that, by applying Thoma Bravo’s expertise, operational framework and experience, we can support the business and accelerate its evolution and growth.”

The Sophos deal is the latest UK listed company to be taken private in recent months as US buyout funds race to deploy billions in unspent capital.

So far this year, there have been seven public-to-private deals in the UK with an aggregate value of $12.7bn, according to data provider Preqin.

Advent made a £4 billion bid to buy UK aerospace and engineering firm Cobham, while a consortium which included Blackstone and Lego’s founding family took Merlin Entertainments private in a deal that valued the world’s second biggest operator of theme parks after Disney at just under $6bn, including debt.

“Another day, another takeover of a UK company by a foreign business...”, said Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.
